I'm having a weird bug. I have an Android project with a launcher activity which goes to login activity which goes to home activity. If on home activity I press home button then the app minimises and if I come back to app my home activity is open, but if I press back button and come back to my app it starts the app from launcher activity
I have oneplus3 oxygen is 4.0.2 Nougat
But I confirmed this behaviour on stock android 4.4.2
Is this intended or a bug?
I tested it with my own project and another person's project also but this behaviour is occurring.
Intended
Home minimises, back removes last activity from stack (unless onBackPressed is overridden)
So when you reopen after clicking back, there’s no stack to restore state from, so you get a fresh app session
So is the way to restore state when coming back is saving it in onSaveInstance()?
Will it call restore state function even if the activity was finished?
If the activity is finished like that then no, you need other methods for restoring, like writing to a DB
If you really want to that is
But there’s not really any cases where that’d be necessary
(I’m sure there’s a few, but they’re not common)
So saving and restoring state is useful in case of minimise by home button?
Strange I never noticed it till now. I thought I was not coding correctly.
It’s a bit more in depth than that, but essentially yes
<https://developer.android.com/guide/components/activities/index.html>

attachments.title: Activities | Android Developers
attachments.text: Improve your app's performance by learning how to optimize power consumption, launch times, and other important areas of performance.

text: Back is essentially the same as calling onDestroy
<https://developer.android.com/guide/components/activities/activity-lifecycle.html>

attachments.title: The Activity Lifecycle | Android Developers
attachments.text: An Activity is an application component that provides a screen with which users can interact in order to do something, such as dial the phone, take a photo, send an email, or view a map. Each activity is given a window in which to draw its user interface…

Hey, when obfuscating code with proguard, this line works:
`proguardFiles getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android-optimize.txt'), '<http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro>'`
while this doesn't:
`consumerProguardFiles getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android-optimize.txt'), '<http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro>'`
and I want to use it so devs using my lib won't need to change their proguard file
anyone stumbled around this?
lol <@U0N7D6F50> there's no links in my post :face_with_rolling_eyes:
<@U2QKJRNGZ> you aren't setting it up correctly.
The proguard.txt file is something you define with your own rules for your library.

<@U05473HHT> I've defined it, it worked in the first line (without consumer)
the consumerProguardFiles is configured differently?
I've changed <http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro> to what I wanted to keep
AFAIK proguard.txt is old, it is now built automatically from <http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro>
Yeah, consumerProguardFiles is the rules for your library.
So if you notice that Proguard strips out Classes from your library that are actually needed, then you would need to write a rule to keep it.
I know
I did that already
and it works with the `proguardFiles` command
but when I change it to `consumerProguardFiles` it stops working
You would define the consumerProguardFiles in your library and then in the app you would just define normal proguardFiles.
The consumerProguardFiles just needs to know your rules and what I posted above is the syntax for setting it up. I use it for an internal library at work.
yea, so that's exactly what I'm trying to do :slightly_smiling_face:
but when defining consumerProguardFiles for my library it ignores the -keep in my <http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro>
What do you have your -keep rule as?
again, when I minify the library with `proguardFiles getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android-optimize.txt'), '<http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro>'` it works
<@U05473HHT> Any ideas?
The rule looks right to me. Not really sure why you are having issues.
<@U05473HHT> how does the line from your project looks like?
So in my lib/build.gradle I have what I posted above for defining the consumerProguardFile.
Then I just have a rule to not modify a certain Class at all.
and you're using `'proguard.txt'` directly? not through `<http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro>` ?
My file is actually named <http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro> but in my lib directory. All I have is just one line to not modify a certain class.

then over in app/build.gradle, I just apply proguard with the proguardFiles with `proguardFiles getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android.txt'), '<http://proguard-rules.pro|proguard-rules.pro>'
`

minifyEnabled true
is also in the defaultConfig or that's in buildTypes.release ?
I have that in my buildTypes.release
yes
